Description: Upper body sherd of large Chian Mature Animal Style pottery chalice; creamy slip; interior glazed streaky black with part of lotus flower in added red and white; below, two wide bands in white with added red lines; exterior, from top: part of billet pattern; two narrow brown bands; painted decoration consisting of bull (top of head with horn, ear, neck and eye remaining) to left; pendant roundel, elaborate rosettes and circles as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos places this sherd in the Middle Wild Goat II period. However, the decoration on the interior surface of the sherd suggests that the sherd is slightly later and would find its place in the Mature Animal Style group where bulls are frequently portrayed.
Bibliographic references: CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 34, no. 32, pl. XVII)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 241, no. 227, pl. 18)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0605) (phase 2)
